Summary: Trump is considering a “domestic gag rule” which would essentially apply the same restrictions as the global rule (where NGOs cannot actively promote abortion as a method of family planning). Would force PP to either stop discussing abortion with their patients or stop receiving Title X funds (federal grant for family planning services).

Renewable energy developers are worried about a ballot campaign aiming to double Michigan’s renewable portfolio standard to 30% by 2020. Concerned it will make renewable energy a political issue again.
Michigan’s small business climate is losing momentum having dipped in its “entrepreneurial climate” score since 2016.
Voter turnout for the May vote (focused mostly on school millage and bond requests) was so small it’s sparking interest in consolidating Michigan’s election calendar (i.e. eliminating May elections).

Political parties are showing increased interest in the upcoming Michigan State University board election (the first since the Nassar trails). Voters this fall will be replacing two Republican trustees (currently the board is split evenly between Dems and Repubs.)
Much better link to watch the debate from last week.

State staffers in Schuette’s office were involved in at least four private real estate transactions in the Virgin Islands. Schuette has been accused of violating his pledge to put assets into a blind trust. Schuette argues the property was never part of the blind trust as it does not represent a conflict.

Appeals court refuses to dismiss a lawsuit by PP over Centre for Medical Progress videos allegedly showing the illegal sale of fetal tissue. PP says the center deceptively edited and created false videos that were posted online.
Michigan House votes to loosen mining permit laws. Mining companies would be able to modify onsite facilities without an environmental permit amendment under the new legislation.

Attorneys for Michigan Department of Health and Human Services Director say notes from a September 2015 conference call prove their client put the office of Gov. Rick Snyder on notice about outbreaks of Legionnaires' disease in Flint months before the governor told the public.

Michigan income tax and sales tax are higher than expected and should give lawmakers approximately $500 million in budget surplus. The money will be used to boost spending on infrastructure, school safety initiatives and pay down debts. The elevated projections are said to reflect a stronger economy and “disciplined state budgets”.
Michigan State U settles Nassar Lawsuit for $500 million.

Dem: El-Sayed
Good article covering El-Sayed. Details his history with Duggan, Mayor of Detroit - El-Sayed had expected to get an endorsement from Duggan, but he instead endorsed Whitmer.

Civil Rights Commission said Monday that gay and transgender residents should be protected under current state law. The commission held that existing protections against sex discrimination should also hold for sexual orientation and gender identity. Critics claim the panel exceeded its authority, consider legal action.

Schuette signs amiscus brief (advises courts of relevant info or arguments to consider) in case of Ohio Planned Parenthood vs. Ohio Department of Health regarding an attempt to cut federal funding for Ohio Planned Parenthood clinics.

Michigan is approaching completion on new water regulations for lead. It is the strictest plan to date and would result in the replacement of all lead service pipes in Michigan. Local government and water utilities oppose the regulations, claiming they are an overreaction in response to Flint, and will be costly and largely ineffective.

Detroit Renewable Power, a solid waste incinerator, has a history of exceeding pollution emissions standard. The Department of Environmental Quality, in negotiations with Michigan Attorney General’s Office, has cited the company for only 8 pollution incidents, though records show they’ve exceeded emissions standards hundreds of times. Environmental groups want the incinerator to face more penalties, some calling for it to be shut down.
An article reviewing the Republican candidate’s stances on transparency as well as their financial disclosures to Bridge. Provides a more in-depth review of Schuette’s real estate assets.

A minimum wage ballot initiative backed by Michigan One Fair Wage has been submitted Monday with over 370,000 signatures. The proposal would raise Michigan’s minimum wage to $12 by 2022. The ballot is opposed by state business groups.
An extensive review of the ways in which Michigan’s education system is failing students. Points to low rates of educational attainment and how this impacts economic growth.

Rep: Schuette   Schuette was at the White House May 18th participating in a discussion on the future of criminal justice reform. He highlighted a need to reduce barriers to prisoners reentering society, including reducing licensure requirements for skilled trades and literacy education in prisons.
Rep: Schuette + Calley Calley is now calling for an independent investigation of Schuette alleging that the real estate dealing he did while in office (notarized by office staff) broke the law.

Dem: Thanedar     Interview detailing attacks Thanedar made on other democratic opponents. Calling El-Sayed “just a rich kid” and claiming Whitmer “hasn’t had anything to show as her accomplishments.”
Good, quick overview of all the candidates.

Libertarians are included in the upcoming primary (the first time since 1998 that a third party has qualified to hold a primary in Michigan). The contested primary means Libertarian issues will be brought to the political conversation and has the potential to sway “Michigan’s famously independent, swing voters.”

More information on Title X funding and how Trumps announcement will impact Planned Parenthood. Title X specifically serves those who don’t have Medicaid, meaning cutting this funding will directly impact a vulnerable population.

Michigan House has approved a bill that gives industry representatives a larger role in environmental regulation. The legislation creates private-sector panels (populated mostly by industry representatives) that could override agency decisions on rules and permits.
About 100 protesters gathered at Snyder’s office yesterday to demand the state continue to provide bottles water to Flint residents. Water distribution was ended last month.

While educational outcomes have improved across the nation, Michigan continues to fall behind on test scores, on-time graduations and secondary school numbers. Many see the K-12 system as severely hurt by bad policies around school choice, many leading back to Betsy DeVoss (a supporter of Schuette). This article explores various aspects of the debate via a number of experts and education advocates.
Rep: Schuette.  Schuette signs Americans for Tax Reform pledge to never raise taxes because he “will be Michigan's jobs and paychecks governor”.

Dem: Thanedar   Thanedar has hired David Bullock to manage his statewide campaign. Bullock is a prominent Detroit activist and pastor and is well known in the community. Shows Thanedar making an active push for support in Detroit.

Democrats.    El-Sayed and Whitmer have released details about their finances to Bridge Magazine. Thanedar has refused to disclose his finances despite multiple statements voicing support for transparency from state elected leaders. Article details what each candidate has disclosed in response to Bridge’s request.

Planned Parenthood considering litigation against Trump if he moves forward with proposed cut to Title X funding. The National Family Planning and Reproductive Health Association, a membership organization of Title X family planning clinics, also said it would consider litigation.

Snyder has approved an emergency order yesterday prohibiting ships from dropping anchors in the Straits of Mackinac following an April act that ruptured transmission cables and dented Line 5. The rule prohibits boats from deploying, dragging, setting or otherwise using an anchor in a defined area of the straits, except in cases of emergency.

New poll found 54% of Michigan voters want the Line 5 oil pipeline in the Straits of Mackinac to be shut down, 87% of voters said they are concerned that the 65-year-old pipeline could have oil spill in Northern Michigan.

Pair of legal challenges filed Monday State regulators failed to enforce environmental laws when they allowed additional structural supports for Line 5 without proper review. Claim Michigan DEQ didn't appropriately evaluate alternatives and the potential for damaging environmental effects when they granted permits earlier this year for Enbridge to install new screw anchors.
Michigan has seen higher interest in guns over the past few months - stats show there has been an increase in sales and concealed pistol licenses issued since the Parkland shooting.

While Michigan provides free, state-funded preschool for 4-year-olds from low-to-moderate-income families, it offers little financial help for families with children ages three and younger. Michigan’s childcare assistance for children under 4 has some of the most restrictive income eligibility requirements in the nation.

Rep: Schuette
Calley’s recent ad attacks Schuette’s flip-flopping on various issues including abortion. Bridge looks into the truth behind the claim and finds that Schuette’s rhetoric around abortion has shifted. In his early political campaigns in the 80s, his stance was-  personally opposed to abortion but in favor of abortion rights.

Rep: Schuette 
Schuette discloses his personal finances that show assets totaling more than $13M.

Rep: Schuette
Video of Schuette speaking on fixing Michigan roads: need to have warranties on roads, some form of guarantee’s, a “clean fresh scrub” of the transportation policy.

Rep: Schuette
In depth article outlining Schuette’s political history, looks into inconsistencies in his stances (which have shifted more to the right in recent years).

Dem: Thanedar
Video surfaces of Thanedar at a Republican rally for Mark Rubio in 2016. Video shows him clapping and seeking out a photo with the U.S. senator from Florida. Two Michigan political consultants have claimed that Thanedar has initially not been sure if he would run as a Democrat or Republican, questioning his stance as the “most progressive” candidate.

Dem: Whitmer
Whitmer facing challenge of being widely unknown by those outside of Democratic circles.  A recent poll showed 54% of 600 people surveyed didn't recognize her name among the Democratic candidates, compared with 31% for Thanedar and 47% for El-Sayed.

Dem: Whitmer
Gretchen Whitmer has released a plan called the “Michigan Sunshine Plan”, outlining how she would reform Michigan state government by making it more open, transparent and accountable to taxpayers. Schuette has announced a similar plan.

Twitter says it’s adding special labels to tweets from some U.S. political candidates, including candidates for governor, ahead of this year’s midterm elections. The labels will include what office a person is running for and where.

Redistricting group, trying to change the way Michigan draws political boundaries, rallied Thursday at the Capitol and urged state officials to put the proposal on the November ballot despite a legal challenge.
*Not Michigan specific - Ireland has voted to legalize abortion up to 12 weeks, a landmark decision with global implications.

Michigan House Republicans are warming up to the idea of approving and later amending a marijuana legalization initiative. However, it is still not likely that the 55 votes required for House passage will be secured by the June 5 deadline.

Flint officials say there are more damaged lead and galvanized water service lines buried than previously estimated with an estimated 14,000 lines remaining buried. Efforts to replace the lines will continue throughout the year.

Article detailing the positive economic impacts of fishing and hunting in Michigan (support more than 70,000 jobs and generate about $5 billion annually). These activities also contribute huge amounts of funding to restoration and conservation efforts on public lands.

This week is the Mackinac Policy Conference this week. Focus will be on the following themes: Michigan's preparedness and competitiveness for business investment, readiness for next-generation mobility and trust in government, media and business institutions. **During the conferance there will be a gubernatorial debate.

Dates for upcoming debates.
May 31st: Top three candidates from both parties debate (live streamed on the Detroit Regional Chamber's website)
June 20th: Democratic candidates debate (WOOD-TV)
June 28th: Republican candidates debate (WDIV-TV)
July 19th: Democratic candidates debate (WDIV-TV)

Line 5 is not on the agenda for the Mackinac Policy Conference starting today, angering environmental advocates. The Great Lakes Business Network (a group concerned over line 5) is planning a news conference tomorrow morning to release a new study
Members of Oil and Water Don't Mix are planning a protest for today as people arrive for the Mackinac Policy Conference.

Rep: Schuette 
Article written by Schuette detailing how he will cut taxes. Specifically attacks Calley, contrasting their tax approaches and details plans to bring up the issue of taxes at the debate this week.
Memorial day weekend involved multiple shootings in Detroit with a total of 8 fatalities. May reignite debate over gun issues.

Infrastructure and road repairs is a recurring issue throughout Michigan. Recent survey shows 89% of respondents think Michigan's road and bridge quality is "fair or poor", but over 60% would not be willing to pay more in taxes or fees to support state transportation improvements.

Michigan Campaign Finance Network reports that of the 30 largest legislative leadership political action committees, 24 of them are Republican. Collectively these 30 PACs have raise $3.4 million, with Republicans out fundraising Democrats by a 6 to 1 margin.

Recent study states Line 5 puts Michigan at risk for an environmental disaster but has evolved into what is mostly a shortcut for a Canadian company to move Canadian oil to Canadian refineries. i.e. Canada receives the economic benefits of the line, while Michigan receives very few.

Dem: Whitmer and Thanedar 
Whitmer and Thanedar roll out economic plans. Thanedar wants to eliminate income taxes for low-income residents but raise taxes $3.6 billion on corporations and wealthy individuals. Whitmer calls for $100 million a year in new spending to create new college scholarships and skills training programs.

Rep: Schuette
Schuette talked to voters about various issues at his annual barbecue in Presque Isle yesterday. Topics included high auto insurance rates and quality of Michigan education and spending. Schuette stressed his plan to cut taxes.

The Supreme Court Decision yesterday rejected Planned Parenthood's challenge to an Arkansaw abortion law that made accessing medication abortions extremely difficult. Planned Parenthood will continue their fight against the law.

A settlement for Flint children over the water crisis is expected to be resolved this summer. So far a judge has a approved a partial settlement giving universal screenings for learning disabilities for all Flint children affected by lead-contaminated water and creating a neurodevelopmental center for deeper assessments.

Dem: El-Sayed
Interviewed at the Mackinac Policy Conference , thinks this conference is what its wrong with politics - "folks in power get together and talk about how to keep power." Also touches on his universal healthcare plan.

Dem: Whitmer
Americans For Prosperity, a conservative advocacy group backed by the Koch brothers, is running an online ad targeting Whitmer, claiming she has supported tax increases that led to the loss of hundreds of thousands of jobs in Michigan. The Bridge Truth Squad calls the ad "half-accurate" - Whitmer has supported tax increases but the ad is misleading in its insineuation that tax increases cause Michigan's mass job loss.

Dem: Thanedar
Thanedar has released his 2015 and 2016 tax returns and other financial details. He has assets of approximately $30 million, most likely making him the wealthiest candidate in the race.

More than 100 low-income voters from Detroit and Flint plan to stage a "die-in" protest at Schuette's office today at 12:30. They are protesting Schuette's opposition to thet state's Medicaide expansion

Michigan may be the hardest hit were a “trade war” between the US and China to erupt. A research analyst at the Brookings Institution in Washington stated this week - more than 91,000 Michigan jobs in industries, including auto-making, plastic product manufacturing and pharmaceuticals, could be lost if China were to stand by a tax threat made in April. On Tuesday, Trump said he is considering a 25% tariff on $50 billion worth of Chinese imports.

During a visit from Betsy DeVos to a Grand Rapids public school on Tuesday, a student wore a transgender pride flag to deliver a message on protecting LGBTQ rights in schools. In 2017, DeVoc rescinded protections enacted under Obama allowing transgender studnets to use the school bathrooms that matched their gender identity.
Study released this week ("Canada's Profits, Michigans Risk") shows that other existing pipelines in North America could sufficiently supply Michigan with oil if Line 5 is shut down.

An employee of Progress Michigan has filed a lawsuit against Schuette, alleging the gubernatorial candidate has violated the state constitution and civil service rules by using his office for political patronage and his state employees for campaign purposes. A key accusation is that  Schuette loaded his taxpayer-funded office with Republican campaign activists in the run-up to his 2018 gubernatorial bid.

Debate: Whitmer
-blasted Schuette for fighting a right-to-literacy lawsuit in court
-has a $3 billion plan to "fix the damn roads," the money could come from approved bonding or tax raises 
-supported graduated income tax
-criticized current government for Flint and allowing Nestle to pump Michigan water 
-to bolster education on the state, need to stop redistributing money from School Aid Fund

Debate: Schuette
-called Whitmer's plans for more taxes an "economic collapse plan"
-supports repealing the state's wage law as part of a plan to fix infrastructure (use savings from not having to pay union wages)
-wants to rollback of the state income tax hike, from 4.25% to 3.9%
-frequently touted his supported from Trump 
-called for a review of the Michigan Department of Transportation
-expressed support for Medicaid work requirement 
-supports cutting auto insurance rates, claiming will help stimulate the economy

Debate
Some other key points from debate: 
-El-Sayed criticized the many lobbyists in the room, saying they paid off politicians to keep their taxes low
-Colbeck attacked El-Sayed again using islamophobic rhetoric 
-Calley calls education his "number one priority"
-Flint was a recurring theme with El-Sayed and Thanedar using it as a symbol for the breakdown of trust in government

More than 100 low-income voters went ahead with a protest yesterday outside Schuette's office. The group was protesting Schuette's campaign pledges to cut Michigan's Medicaid expansion. The cuts could affect nearly 700,000 people in Michigan who rely on Medicaid.

Dem: Thanedar
On Friday, the Michigan Board of State Canvassers rejected El-Sayed's challenge to Thanedar's voting signatures. El-Sayed had filed a grievance claiming that Thanedar's petition signatures contained a number of errors.

New laws went into effect Friday that are aimed at reducing patient's risk of opioid addiction. Prescribers of drugs like Vicodin and morphine are now required to educate patients on the risks of addiction, and patients must sign a form saying they've been informed. They're also required to check a patients prescription history, meaning longer wait times.

Tuesday is the deadline for the legislature to either move ahead on approving the legalization of recreational marijuana or to leave it up to voters in November. Supporters turned in more than 300,000 petition signatures to put the issue on the November ballot.  The initiative would legalize and regulate marijuana for recreational use for Michiganders over 21 years old.
Snyder has voiced in an interview that fixes will only be temporary and Line 5 should eventually be de-commissioned.

More than a dozen governors have said they will take legal action against the Trump administration if they move ahead with cutting Title X funding to clinics. The governors sent a letter Thursday to the  Health and Human Services Secretary, emphasizing the importance of protecting Title X.

A "yes means yes" bill has been sponsored by a Michigan Democrat and is awaiting a house vote. The bill aims to introduce relationship violence and consent as mandatory topics in sex education in Michigan public schools.

Snyder's administration is in talks with Enbridge regarding a utility corridor ("the tunnel"). Enbridge is expected to submit an alternatives report by June 15th outlining potential costs, engineering considerations and environmental impacts. The Great Lakes Business Network has released a report outlining an alternative propane pipeline that would end before the straits.
Today is the deadline for  lawmakers to approve a proposal to legalize marijuana. If not approved today it will end up on the November ballot.

The Aug. 7 primary will be the first statewide election in which every city and township will use all new voting equipment that includes optical-scan ballot tabulators, accessible voting devices for voters with disabilities, and election-management and reporting software.

[Rep: Schuette] Schuette continues to use Granholm's legacy (Michigan governor before Snyder) as a campaign issue. Schuette is trying to associate Granholm with Whitmer and Calley, using them to contrast his stance on taxes and spending - positing himself as the "jobs governor" who will cut taxes.

Planned Parenthood has launched an online tracking tool called Tracking Trump. It outlines how the Trump-Pence administration is attacking people's reproductive and sexual health rights with a timeline of events, list of key players and descriptions of specific policies. It also has a chrome extension  to alert you of new events!

Michigan lawmakers could vote this week on a legislative initiative to eliminate the state's prevailing wage for public construction projects. Republican house members support the initiative, stating it will save taxpayer dollars on public projects - they are pushing to vote on it this week. Democrats are against the initiative as the state currently has labor shortages in the building trades.

Schools are closed for the day in a southwestern Michigan district after comments were overheard referencing violence against the school and graffiti referencing guns was found. The schools are scheduled to reopen Wednesday with increased police presence.
[Rep: Schuette] Mike Pence is expected to attend a private fundraiser in Michigan this month for Schuette. The event is June 15th.
Progress Michigan has made a site and story book detailing the ties between DeVoss and Schuette. Betsy DeVoss' organizations have donated $122K to Scheutte's campaign.
Legalization of marijuana is going to ballot this November, a win for marijuana advocates. If it had been approved through legislature yesterday, it would've been open to changes.

House legislators are expected to vote today on eliminating the prevailing wage for public construction projects. It currently requires contractors to pay workers union wages and benefits for state-funded construction projects .Union groups have urged legislators to vote no on the repeal and put it on the ballot for November.

Koch brothers are opposing Trump tariffs, investing millions in a multi-year campaign pushing the benefits of free trade. They are urging the Trump administration to lift the recent tariffs on aluminum and steel imports as well as proposed tariffs on imports from China. The brothers have spent millions supporting conservative policies but don't quite see eye-to-eye with Trump.

[Macomb Forum] Both El-Sayed and Thanedar will be participating the Macomb democratic gubernatorial forum Monday night, speaking about their platforms. Whitmer is unable to attend. A GOP forum is also taking place, but Schuette will not be in attendance.

[Rep: Schuette] Republican leaders of Michigan House of Representatives and Senate have asked Schuette to give an opinion stating the Michigan Civil Rights Commission overstepped its authority when it states discrimination complaints should also cover the LGBT community. His office has not yet responded.
Medicaid work requirement approved by Michigan House. It would require Michiganders to work 80 hours a month in order to receive Medicaid.
Michigan Republicans repealed the prevailing wage law yesterday (for public construction projects). The vote was opposed by Democrats and union-backed labor groups.

[Dem: El-Sayed] El-Sayed has revealed his universal health care proposal. It involved raising taxes on large businesses and individuals to pay for a universal "Michicare" - estimated to save $5000 a year in health care related savings for the average Michigan family.

[Rep: Colbeck] Detailed article about Colbeck, considered the most conservative candidate. It covers his history, stances on major issues and his distancing from the GOP following islamophobic comments made towards El-Sayed.

A bill reported out of a Senate committee Tuesday would exempt Michigan utilities from personal property taxes on their transmission lines and pipelines - claim it will protect Michigan electricity customers from higher rates. Opponents fear it could cost local governments $576.3 million annually within 10 years.

Chemicals used to water-proof clothing, shoes, carpeting, non-stick cookware and fire fighting foam have been found to be contaminating 23 sites near Clinton River and Lake St. Clair in St. Clair and Macomb counties Michigan. "We call them legacy pollution," said Bob Allison, deputy director of the Michigan League of Conservation Voters. "Forever chemicals. These things don't go away."

Schuette is saying that "Michigan […] is last in the nation in third-grade reading" - based on a misinterpretation of one line in the introduction to one report, with no data to back it up. The average fourth-grader in Michigan is reading at a grade level 1.5 grades lower than the average Massachusetts fourth-grader, according to the National Assessment of Educational Progress, as one example. And Michigan ranks in the bottom third of states nationally in most subjects and grades tested by NAEP.

Michigan AG Schuette debuts new OK2SAY initiative, a 4-year old program that will unveil a new feature - student ambassadors. The program aims to bring kindness, inclusion, and awareness activities and ideas into schools.

Democratic members of the House Committee on Education and the Workforce are calling on Education Secretary Betsy DeVos to explain how the school safety commission that she chairs will study gun violence as part of its work. The commission, which was set up after the deadly shooting in Parkland, Florida, would not focus on how guns contribute to school violence.

The Republican-led Michigan Legislature on Thursday gave final approval to a bill requiring able-bodied adults in the state's Medicaid expansion program to meet work or job-related requirements, sending it to Gov. Rick Snyder for his expected signature. By 2020, adults age 18 to 62 would have to show workforce engagement averaging 80 hours a month — through work, school, job or vocational training, an internship, substance abuse treatment or community service.

At a press conference held Thursday outside the Capitol Building, the members of Congress, along with pro-life group Live Action, asked the Department of Health and Human Services to investigate Planned Parenthood and other Title X fund recipients to determine if there is a widespread practice of covering up sexual abuse.

[Dem: Whitmer] Whitmer released a new 11-page education policy platform calling for more state spending to phase in universal preschool, give districts extra money to hire additional literacy coaches, hire more counselors and potentially increase educator pay.

DTE announces plans to open another plan that would emit pollution in East China Township. Residents have different views about the new facility (to be completed by 2022) - it was okayed by the Michigan Public Service Commission despite opposition from a number of environmental groups.
[Rep: Schuette] Schuette writes article highlighting the need for ethics reform in Michigan - calling for stricter ethics laws and stating, as governor, he would make reforms happen.
Michigan Progressive Summit is happening on June 16th in Flint - an event for progressive activists in Michigan to network and skill-build.

One Fair Wage, a proposal to incrementally raise the minimum wage to $12 by 2022, could appear on the general election ballot in November. The law would highly impact the restaurant industry. Currently, tip credit allows employers to pay tipped employees as little as $3.52 an hour. Tipping culture also adversely impacts women and POC. Opposition (including the Michigan Restaurant Association) claim it would increase restaurant owners’ labor costs by 241% and could mean huge job loss.

Residents in Grand Rapids are calling for an investigation into soil quality after generations of high cancer rates. The local Butterworth landfill has a history of soil contamination and has been previously investigated by the EPA.
Environmentalists planning to speak out today about the dangers of Line 5 prior to Enbridge releasing an alternatives report this week. Enbridge is expected to support the utility tunnel method.

[Dem: Whitmer] Build a Better Michigan, a group aligned with  Whitmer, launched today a five-week, $1.8 million advertising campaign putting her in television ads for the first time this cycle. These are "issue ads" featuring Whitmer but not directly advocating for her election.

[Dem: El-Sayed] El-Sayed announces plan to reduce auto insurance rates by prohibiting insurers from using non-driving factors to determine rates, creating a “Truth in Insurance Commission” to oversee the industry, capping hospital charges and restricting attorney access to accident reports.
Enbridge to release alternatives report this Friday, expected to support a utility tunnel. Environmentalists still oppose this approach.

[Rep: Calley] In depth interview with Calley. Topics include: education as his top priority, increasing school security to combat school shootings, creating more jobs will allow more people to have health insurance coverage and how Michigan can deal with water contamination.

A bill that would create "citizen panels" of people with special interest and expertise in different areas and allow them to oversea decisions made by the MDEQ has been approved by Senate. Opponents argue the panels would be made of industry officials who want to have a say  in environmental policy and regulation - a clear conflict of interest.

Changes to the state budget detail how Michigan's lowest performing schools will face consequences if they don't meet specific measurable academic outcomes within a specified time frame. Consequences include the closure of schools or schools being "reconstituted" if academic improvement goals aren't met.
[Dem: Whitmer] Americans for Prosperity, a conservative group funded by the Koch brothers, has launched a $1.7M television ad campaign attaching Whitmer and linking her to Granholm.
[Rep: Hines] Hines is embracing his position as a outsider in the republican race. This article gives an in depth look at his background, career and reasons behind running for office.

Michigan residents are still concerned over PFA levels in the water. Studies have shown that PFAs toxins pose a threat to drinking water when they accumulate in groundwater and can have adverse health affects. Reports have speculated that the EPA is sitting on a study about the harmful effects of PFAs contaminants because the White House deems it a “public relations nightmare."

A federal judge ruled in favor of two Michigan Christian colleges on Tuesday, allowing them to avoid paying for abortion-related healthcare under an Obama-era mandate. The mandate required health insurance providers, including universities, to supply access to family planning resources including abortions and birth control.

Michigan will finalize the country's toughest lead drinking water rules today. The new rules from the DEQ would lower lead action levels to 12 parts per billion starting in 2025 and require communities across the state to remove all lead service lines. The rule change was initiated in the wake of the Flint water crisis.

Figures released Wednesday show Michigan's unemployment rate was at it's lowest level since last August. Total employment increased by 10,000 during the month of May and the number of unemployed in Michigan fell by 5,000.
[Rep: Schuette] This Friday Mike Pence is attending a fundraiser for Schuette in Michigan. The "Make Michigan Win Again" event is starting at noon in Birmingham.

Michigan’s Republican-led Legislature on Tuesday approved a $56.8 billion budget for next year that seeks to cut aid for Planned Parenthood despite a warning from Snyder the ban may be unconstitutional. The language around PP prohibits the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services from contracting for non-abortion family planning and reproductive services with an entity that also performs abortions. Senate Democrats who still voted for spending bill are confident the governor will declare the Planned Parenthood provision unenforceable

[Rep: Schuette] Bridge Truth Squad examines Schuette's claims that he opposed Obama era environmental protections. Schuette was involved in two lawsuits — one of which he spearheaded — in which he supported the position of coal-fired power plants, whose emissions, studies say, can cause asthma and other health effects.

A group of conservative advocates, including Colbeck, have proposed a new social studies curriculum standard for K-12. The new guide removes climate change as a mandatory teachable and sections where teachers are urged to discuss the accomplishments and setbacks of minority groups. Democrats are calling the new standards "revisionist history."

Mlive, a prominent Michigan news source, has partnered with League of Women Voters of Michigan to provide candidate information and other voting resources to our Michigan readers. The group is a nonpartisan, political organization that encourages informed and active participation in government.

A number of Michigan communities have filed lawsuits against  opioid manufacturers, arguing that they aggressively promoted their products by falsely claiming the drugs aren't addictive. The 1995 Michigan Product Liability Act grants pharmaceutical companies nearly absolute immunity from lawsuits filed by consumers and was co-sponsored by Schuette who was a state senator at the time.
[Dem: Whitmer] Short interview and overview of Whitmer and her platform.

[Dem: El-Sayed] Crain's Detroit Business column about Abdul El-Sayed sparked clashes on social media over whether he inflates his professional status. His doctor credentials are a focal point of his campaign, but he's never actually practiced as a post-medical school doctor.

Bridge Truth Squad tackles claims made on the League of Conservation Voters site attacking Schuette's stance on Line 5. The article calls the claims "mostly accurate" as Schuette could argue in court for a Line 5 shutdown but hasn’t. However, they point out the site could have extra context that a shutdown would require a court order, and that Schuette has still been involved in negotiations concerning Line 5’s safety.

[Rep: Schuette] Pence visited Michigan Friday in support of Schuette. Small protests awaited them at both stops, representatives from both Progress Michigan and Planned Parenthood were present at the protests.

Michigan has been highly impacted by global warming, particularly the Lower Peninsula, which since 1988 has experienced a 2.16-degree Fahrenheit temperature increase. The higher temperatures have impacted the tourism industry, forcing a shorter winter ski season.

The report from Enbridge delivered to Snyder on Friday claims a new tunnel underneath the straits is a viable option to replace line 5 after undergoing a feasibility study. The tunnel is the costliest option, requiring up to $500 million and up to six years to complete, but was also deemed the least environmentally risky. LCV criticized the company's failure to consider a replacement option outside of the straits.

Michigan Democrats have introduced a bill that would change the voting age to 16, inspired by the outpouring of young activism following the Parkland shooting. The bill is unlikely to get a hearing or vote in the GOP-controlled House and Senate, but could become a talking point during the upcoming election season.
The first Democrat-only televised debate is happening this Wednesday. The three candidates will tout their agendas to a broader audience. Whitmer is expected to announce her own health care plan.

Legislation proposing Michigan drop its stringent ballast water discharge rules and adopt federal regulations for ocean freighters was approved by the House this week. Environmentalists are urging Snyder to veto the bill over concerns of invasive species.

Trump's zero tolerance immigration policy is a divisive topic right now, causing a rift between Republicans. It's impacts are felt in Michigan where two Michigan foster care agencies hold contracts with the federal government and are licensed to find foster homes for immigrant children separated from their families.
[Dem: Whitmer] Whitmer has snagged some key endorsements in her run for governor - Macomb County Sheriff,  Prosecutor and Executive have chosen to back her.

Teen births have hit a record low in Michigan, as a decades-long trend downwards continues to accelerate, based on state data. Experts credit a number of factors for the decline including the use of more effective birth control.

Wolverine World Wide has begun to sample soil, sediment and groundwater at their former tannery to determine how toxic the property is following an order from the EPA. Sediment testing in a nearby river found elevated levels of arsenic, lead and mercury. The site was found to have high PFA levels in November.

Whitmer and El-Sayed are the first candidates to ask for public financing ahead of the primary. Schuette, Calley and Colbeck have each told the state they could make similar requests in the next seven weeks. Michigan makes public funding available to all gubernatorial candidates, who can typically qualify for up to $990,000 for the primary in a 2-1 match on donations made by state residents.

Launch Michigan, a new effort launching in Michigan, includes more than 30 organizations representing labor, business, philanthropy, education and community. Their purpose is to support strategies that have been proven by research to deliver effective education to students, and stick with them beyond election cycles.

Not a single teacher or member of the public spoke in favor of the proposed changes to Michigan's social studies curriculum at the listening session hosted by the Michigan Department of Education. Many were outraged at the possibility of removing mentions of Islam, civil rights efforts of minorities and the word 'democratic' from the civics adage 'core democratic values.

Tonight the Democratic candidates are debating. The three agree on many issues, like raising the minimum wage to $15 an hour, spending more on roads and other infrastructure, shutting down the pipelines in the straits and repealing the state's emergency manager law. But there are also many differences which should make for an interesting debate tonight - including their healthcare proposals and how they will approach taxes.

Michigan Department of Civil Rights releases a statement regarding the zero tolerance immigration policy after receiving an influx of children from the border, some as young as 3 months of age. In the statement they describe their opposition to the forced separation of children from their parents.

Summary of Democratic Debate:  Candidates found common ground on a number of topics - shutting down line 5, legalizing marijuana and ending family separation at the border (*which Trump ended Wednesday). Candidates discussed different approaches to healthcare, how they would pay to fix Michigan's infrastructure problems and how to improve gun control. Whitmer had a strong performance.

[Rep: Schuette] Michigan GOP addressed an email sent out that appeared to show the state party supporting Scheutte's run for governor, stating the email was sent out with MRP's knowledge. The Michigan Republican Party does not endorse in open and contested primaries.

[Rep: Schuette] Schuette has released an attack ad on Calley, targeting his time at Harvard as "wasting taxpayers time and money". The ad said Calley, who serves as president over the Senate, collected his roughly $123,900 salary while missing one-third of Senate session days in 2013 and 2014.

[Rep: Calley]  Calley came out with a new ad featuring two victims of former Michigan State University sports doctor Larry Nassar. In the 30-second commercial released less than a week after Calley signed sexual assault statute of limitation extensions into law, victims of Nasser praised Calley who “listened,” “while some politicians grandstanded.”

Hundreds of gun rights activists from across Michigan gathered at the Capitol yesterday to demonstrate their right to openly carry their guns and advocate for protecting the Second Amendment during the annual Second Amendment March. Schuette, Calley and Colbeck were all in attendance and spoke at the event.

The 2019 state budget signed by Snyder won't shift federal money for pregnancy prevention and family planning services away from Planned Parenthood. The budget, which had been approved by the Legislature, would have moved federal Title X money for family planning services to health clinics and county health departments that do not provide abortions.

Though research has shown that abstinence-only sex education is highly ineffective — and can even be harmful — there are schools across the country that continue to teach it. Planned Parenthood has now filed a lawsuit against the Department of Health and Human Services official responsible for pushing abstinence-only education on American students.

Michigan officials claim they have no involvement in tracking 54 immigrant children placed in foster care in the state after being separated from their families at the U.S.-Mexico border. Snyder made a statement that no state agency has been provided with names, ages or any other identifying information about the children, so they are "unable to track where they are placed or how they are cared for."

Protests against immigration tactics under Trump are being planned throughout the state of Michigan. There has been bipartisan backlash to family separation and a large number of Republicans have opposed Trump on the policy.

Michigan energy suppliers say proposed actions by the Trump administration to declare an energy state of emergency are unnecessary and could lead to higher electric bills for customers. Trump is moving to slow the shutdown of nuclear and coal power plants, making good on his campaign promise to save the coal industry.

[Dem: Thanedar] David Bullock, a pastor and lead campaign manager for Thanedar was arrested Sunday for allegedly interfering with a police investigation. In a statement Thanedar said he supported Bullock and demanded an investigation of the officers involved in the arrest.
Reminder: Thursday, June 28, WDIV-Local 4 and the Michigan Republican Party will host "Decision 2018: Republican Gubernatorial Debate" with the four leading GOP candidates for Michigan governor.

[Dem: Whitmer] The Michigan Republican Party has asked officials to investigate whether the group Build a Better Michigan violated state campaign finance laws by running $1.8 million in television ads that feature Whitmer. The GOP argues that the ads go beyond "issue advocacy" by identifying Whitmer as a candidate for governor.

A 2016 report commissioned by Snyder estimated a nearly $4 billion annual investment gap on addressing infrastructure improvements and maintenance in the state, but little has been done since then to seriously address the gap. This article provides a more in depth look at road, broadband and water system issues in Michigan.

[Dem: Thanedar] An interesting look at the similarities  in Thanedar's running tactics and those of Trump: "A wealthy first-time candidate prone to lofty, unverifiable claims vaulting to the top of the polls in a high-profile race by wrapping himself in the cloak of a movement he had little connection to before his campaign launch."

Snyder signs Medicaid Work Bill into law, requires able-bodied adults to show workforce engagement averaging 80 hours a month, such as a job, school, vocational training, an internship, substance abuse treatment or community service.

Round up of political ads: Whitmer's first TV ad began airing yesterday - touching on things like raising minimum wage, expanding Medicaid and "fixing the damn roads." Hines releases a number of animated online videos, one depicts Calley and Schuette as swamp creatures. Schuette and Calley continue to run attack ads against each other.

Protesters gathered outside ICE office in Detroit yesterday with the hope of shutting it down. The protest is one of several "Occupy ICE" demonstrations that have popped up around the country in the wake of the zero tolerance immigration policy.

Supreme Court sides with Crisis Pregnancy Centers in ruling that blocks a California law requiring these centers share basic information about the availability of family planning services, prenatal care, and abortion.
Supreme Court upholds Trump's travel ban from predominantly Muslim countries - the decision is a big win for the administration.

Democrats in the state House want to get rid of a law passed by Schuette that protects drug companies that knowingly make or sell harmful drugs. Michigan has been in an opioid crisis for years and many Michigan communities are in the middle of lawsuits against opioid makers.

A township in Southwest Michigan, Oshtemo, has passed a resolution denouncing the indefinite detention of families at the southern U.S. border. The resolution carries no legal weight, but asks the federal government to treat all people respectfully and humanely regardless of citizenship, immediately reunite families separated at the border, respect due process and cease discrimination based on religion.

Schuette has launched a petition in support of the Supreme Court ruling to uphold Trump's travel ban, tweeting: "Yesterday, the Supreme Court upheld President Trump's authority to secure our borders and provide the necessary safety to Americans that has been ignored by past administrations. Join me in supporting this important decision by signing my petition today."

[Dem: Whitmer] An in depth article looking at Whitmer positing her as the establishment front runner for the Democratic nomination since she has secured endorsements of most traditional unions and party leaders. However, her polling lead has evaporated in her wait to run television ads.

[Rep: Schuette] Schuette is seeking to stop a proposal on the November ballot that aims to alter how the state draws political boundaries. The proposal would create an independent redistricting commission to redraw congressional and legislative maps every 10 years.

Supreme Court makes ruling in Janus case - government workers who choose not to join a union cannot be charged for the cost of collective bargaining. Michigan, and Schuette, sided with Janus in the case. The decision overrules a 40-year-old precedent in a Michigan case, Abood v. Detroit Board of Education, which unanimously upheld mandatory public-sector union fees.

Protesters shut down a Kent County commission meeting in an attempt to address the board about on an ICE contract with the Kent County Jail. The contract, signed in 2012 and renewed in late 2017, allows the jail to charge ICE for each day it holds a person with a detainment request. They can be held for up to 3 days until ICE officers pick them up for possible immigration proceedings.

[Dem: Thanedar] Thanedar has released three new ads to air across Michigan. The subjects of these ads are: the influence of big money in Lansing, voter apathy towards establishment candidates, and Michigan's crumbling infrastructure.

Republican candidates for governor on Thursday took the stage for a final pre-primary debate, fielding questions on tax incentives and how to fix the roads without raising taxes. Calley, Colbeck and Hines attached Schuette, while Schuette attached Dems.

Protesters slam GPO on healthcare, wages at Michigan governor debate. Bill Schuette, Michigan's attorney general, was the main focus of protesters’ vitriol. Schuette has pledged to roll back Michigan’s Medicaid expansion if elected and has publicly opposed the Affordable Care Act.

[Rep: Schuette]: The attorney who defended former state representative Cindy Gamrat on criminal official misconduct charges on Thursday calls for grand jury investigation of Attorney General Bill Schuette.

Infrastructure in Michigan continues to be a source of contention for residents across the state. The state Legislature laid out plans in 2015 to commit up to $1.2 billion in additional infrastructure funding by 2021. Part of that funding plan relies on commitments from the state's general fund budget each year.

Outgoing Gov. Rick Snyder has signed a $16.8 billion education budget that includes a sizable increase in base aid for lower-funded K-12 districts in Michigan. Democrats had rejected the proposed budget in the GOP-controlled Legislature, saying it won't be enough to reverse course in Michigan's most cash-strapped districts.

Michigan ranks 33rd in the country for overall child well-being (issues including low reading levels, poverty rates, and available access to healthcare). In Michigan, 17% of children lived in poverty in 2016. Teens not in school and not working hit 53% in the state.

Enbridge Energy Partners has delivered to the State of Michigan three reports that examine possible measures and technologies to mitigate potential leaks from Line 5 in the Straits of Mackinac and at water crossings throughout Michigan. The reports include: Assess technologies that will provide additional leak and coating damage detection benefits over and above technologies, Study options to mitigate the risk of a vessel anchor damaging Line 5 in the straits, List priority waters crossed by Line 5 and assess measures at each crossing to minimize the likelihood and consequences of a spill.

[Dem: Whitmer] Gretchen Whitmer pulls way ahead in latest governor's race poll. Michigan Information & Research Service (MIRS) puts Whitmer at 40%, with Thanedar and El-Sayed at 19% and 17% respectively. The poll was conducted by phone (28% calls to mobile devices) between June 24 and 26.

[Dem: Thanedar] Shri Thanedar's candidacy is worrying some state Democrats, with the largest Democratic Club (based in suburban Detroit) taking the extraordinary step of issuing an "anti-endorsement" of the candidate. Executive board member Colton Dale says, "We really strongly believe that he would not only be a horrible governor if he ever got there, but that he would also really be disastrous for the Michigan Democratic Party if he were our nominee."

[Dem: El-Sayed] El-Sayed talks Education in Grand Rapids. His education planform advocates for universal child care and pre-K, making tuition free for families earning less than $150,000, and he wants to invest $150 million into teachers.

Literacy is not a fundamental right, federal judge in Detroit Schools case says. The lawsuit alleged the conditions of Detroit Public Schools are so poor that children are not receiving a minimally adequate education and are being denied access to literacy on account of their race, which violates their 14th Amendment rights to due process and equal protection.

Gov. Rick Snyder signs two new bills into law that activists argue give polluting companies the ability to undermine state environmental guidelines. Activists argue the laws are a step backwards in a state that has struggled to provide accountability to residents.

With the retirement of Justice Kennedy, Trump has the opportunity to appoint another justice to the Supreme Court. Many speculate that Roe v Wade is at risk of being overturned if another conservative justice takes the bench.

A year ago, the Michigan legislature presented a bill that would require all employers to allow workers to earn paid sick days — time off that could also be used to take care of a sick child, or deal with an emergency. The bill was never passed. In May, another sick leave initiative was filed, which would require large Michigan businesses to provide at least 72 hours of earned sick time per year. If the measure is rejected by the Republican-controlled legislature, it will appear on the November ballot.

Progress Michigan takes their lawsuit against Schuette to the Michigan Supreme Court. The lawsuit alleges that Schuette and his staff are using their private emails for state business, with multiple instances of emails about state business being sent and received by personal email accounts. Schuette's spokesperson called it a "politically motivated law suit against the Attorney General."

Plaintiffs plan to appeal the literacy lawsuit dismissed Friday by a judge in Detroit. The lawsuit accuses Gov. Rick Snyder and other state officials of depriving Detroit children of their right to literacy.

Experts have multiple opinions on how a recent executive order signed by Trump will impact Michigan and the Great Lakes. Trump's new order rescinds a 2010 Obama-era order aimed at protecting U.S. oceans and the Great Lakes. Some view it as a direct attack on the Great Lakes, leaving them vulnerable to oil and gas drilling, others think it strikes a balance between protecting the Great Lakes and supporting job creation and economic activity.
[Rep: Schuette] The prosecutor involved in Progress Michigan's lawsuit against Schuette (regarding misuse of personal email accounts) has referred the investigation to the FBI.

A federal judge on Friday threw out Kentucky's new work requirements for Medicaid coverage in a decision that could affect the similar program proposed in Michigan. Snyder recently signed the Medicaid Work Bill into law.

Citizens Research Council, a non-partisan group, released a report strongly suggesting that Michigan is highly-gerrymandered, with current district maps drawn so that Republicans are ensured disproportionate majorities on both the state and federal levels. The report found a shift to favor Republicans in both federal and state races after the 2000 re-districting. A November ballot proposal would take re-districting power away from the state legislature and give it to a citizen commission - Schuette has petitioned to have the ballot removed.

[Rep: Colbeck] In depth article examining Colbeck and his stances on issues: he is against the state income tax, pro school-choice and advocates for teachers to "arm themselves" in order to keep school zones safe.

[Rep: Schuette] Vice President Mike Pence will attend a fundraising event for Attorney General Bill Schuette's gubernatorial run on Friday, June 15th. Both Pence and President Donald Trump have endorsed Schuette for governor.

[Rep: Schuette] Despite denial from Schuette and staff regarding lawsuit (Schuette using personal emails to conduct state business), Progress Michigan now claims they have proof --  records of the emails. "The idea that his office doesn’t possess these records means he’s either lying or he illegally destroyed the records."

[Dem: Whitmer] Mystery group attacking Whitmer online called "Priorities for Michigan" appears to have ties to the GOP. Priorities for Michigan ads criticize Whitmer for failing to support a single-payer heath care system.
[Rep: Schuette] At a Fourth of July parade, Schuette made a statement regarding the ongoing investigation into his office calling it a smear campaign.
[Dem: El-Sayed] Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, the surprise progressive Democratic winner over incumbent U.S. Rep. Joe Cowley in New York, has endorsed El-Sayed for governor.

[Rep: Schuette] Vice President Mike Pence will attend a fundraising event for Attorney General Bill Schuette's gubernatorial run on Friday, June 15th. Both Pence and President Donald Trump have endorsed Schuette for governor.

[Rep: Schuette] Despite denial from Schuette and staff regarding lawsuit (Schuette using personal emails to conduct state business), Progress Michigan now claims they have proof --  records of the emails. "The idea that his office doesn’t possess these records means he’s either lying or he illegally destroyed the records."

[Dem: Whitmer] Mystery group attacking Whitmer online called "Priorities for Michigan" appears to have ties to the GOP. Priorities for Michigan ads criticize Whitmer for failing to support a single-payer heath care system.

PFAS contamination is being called "Michigan's next water crisis". To date, more than 30 sites in 15 communities across Michigan have confirmed PFAS contamination in the soil, groundwater or surface water. Public health experts link exposure to the chemicals with increased risk for cancer, liver damage and other serious ailments.
Gov. Rick Snyder made a statement yesterday, calling it a “serious matter” that a county prosecutor has forwarded to the FBI a request for a criminal investigation of Schuette.

More than 430,000 signatures were submitted Monday for a 2018 ballot initiative to expand voting in Michigan by allowing absentee ballots to be cast for any reason and implementing measures such as same-day voter registration.
[Dem: Whitmer] An in depth article on Whitmer; details her fight for women's rights during her time in the senate and her willingness to work with Republicans to accomplish policy goals.

[Dem: Whitmer] Whitmer has released a Clean Water Policy that she’ll put in place if she’s elected that would create a Department of the Great Lakes and Fresh Water. She would also work to get rid of Enbridge’s Line 5 oil pipeline under the Straits of Mackinac.
[Rep: Schuette] Another "Schuette Saturday" is taking place this weekend (the 14th), the campaign has sent out emails looking for volunteers to make phone calls and spread Schuette's message.

An investigation by Bridge Magazine has revealed that Michigan leaders have allowed lobbyists and officials with direct relationships to Enbridge to offer extensive input about the fate of the pipeline. The investigation was based on a review of more than 5,700 documents including internal emails. Snyder is set to announce in August whether Michigan will go ahead with the tunnel proposal.
An Indiana Planned Parenthood has closed citing years of growing intimidation and harassment of the center's staff by supporters of anti-abortion groups.
[Dem: Thanedar] Interview with The Intercept reveals Thanedar has limited understanding of the Michigan healthcare system and no clear details on his "single-payer plan".
[Rep: Schuette] Schuette tweets his support of Trump's Supreme Court nominee, Judge Kavanaugh. Kavanaugh

Environmentalists and elected officials are calling for Michigan to take a stronger stand against PFAS contamination, which is making its way from the Great Lakes and its bodies of water into public drinking water sources. PFAS have been linked to cancer, liver damage, birth defects and autoimmune diseases.
[Rep: Schuette] Schuette has filed a request for public funding. Thanedar and Whitmer have already requested the funding, Calley and Colbeck have both indicated they may file for applications.

A new metro Detroit group - Detroit Area Youth Uniting Michigan - is planning a voter registration drive. The group has already held a youth summit and organized a rally to fight against gun violence. The wave of student activism has been inspired by the Feb. 14th school shooting at Stoneman Douglas in Parkland.
Elon Musk took to twitter committing to fund efforts to fix Flint homes that still have contaminated water.
[Rep: Whitmer] Whitmer takes a break from the more serious issues of the campaign, releasing a video of her reading mean tweets.

Many Michigan farmers who supported Trump are feeling strained as they face the repercussions of an intensifying trade war. China has implemented 25 percent tit-for-tat tariffs on soybeans and other imports from the United States, Michigan is a large exporter of soybeans.

[Dem: Whitmer] Whitmer's campaign has released a new television ad this week titled “Grit", highlighting her priorities for making higher education and skills training more affordable to build a talented workforce and raise wages for Michigan families.
[Rep: Schuette] New Schuette ad touting Trump endorsement says he'll get "tough" on illegal immigration and ban sanctuary cities as Michigan governor.

Activists want state legislators to investigate the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality's handling of an expert report that warned of statewide exposure to toxic chemicals called PFAS long before the state took serious steps to address the contamination.

Snyder said Friday that the state of Michigan intends to sue the Minnesota-based manufacturer linked to PFAS contaminated water near military bases and industrial sites, citing "significant costs" that will only rise in the future.

Both Snyder and Trump have prominent roles in new television ads touting Calley and Schuette, respectively. Snyder endorsed Calley as his chosen successor in March, and this week began taking a more active role in the race with the Aug. 7 primary fast approaching.

Article reviewing the spending and tax plans for all the governor candidates. Schuette opposes all new taxes, vows to vote against any and all tax increase, while Whitmer proposes taxes to pay for education reforms and  to "rebuild Michigan bank".
Michigan Democratic Party is hosting the “Decision 2018: Democratic Gubernatorial Debate” with three Democratic candidates for Michigan Govern this Thursday, July 19th, at 8pm.

Several Michigan lawmakers expressed dismay after President Donald Trump on Monday downplayed Russia's interference in the 2016 election. Scheutte's campaign,  which has been trumpeting Trump's endorsement in his Republican run for Michigan governor, didn't respond to a request for comment.

Michigan is the only state in the nation that failed to meet federal special education requirements and requires intervention, according to a U.S. Department of Education evaluation. Michigan's rating came from its high drop-out rate and low graduation rate for students with disabilities

[Schuette and Whitmer] Backers of Schuette point to the involvement in the Whitmer campaign of attorney Mike Nichols and Prosecutor Carol Siemon as evidence Nichols' complaint and Siemon's referral of his complaint to the FBI are politically suspect. The attorney and prosecutor are among dozens of co-hosts for a July 22 fundraiser for Whitmer.

[Rep: Schuette] Reports that Schuette may be under investigation by the FBI are unlikely to sway Republican voters in the Aug. 7 primary, political observers say. Strategists say it's likely that many Republican voters are largely ignoring the controversy.

[Dem: Thanedar] Thanedar is going on the attack with less than three weeks left until Michigan’s Aug. 7 primary, sending  voters a new mailer criticizing Whitmer and suggesting the early Democratic front runner is “firmly in the pocket” of health care executives at Blue Cross Blue Shield of Michigan.

A bipartisan group of Congressional delegates from Michigan  want the Environmental Protection Agency to "immediately" revise and broaden its health guidance for PFAS chemicals and incorporate a new toxicological study that significantly lowers levels at which exposure is considered safe.
[Rep: Schuette] Schuette on Tuesday called Russia a clear adversary to the United States, but he stopped short of criticizing sympathetic comments by President Donald Trump.

An article examining how abortion laws would play out in Michigan were Roe v Wade to be overturned. Since Michigan never repealed the pre-Roe law that banned abortion, if the high court overturned Roe, abortion would be illegal in Michigan.

Supporters of an initiative to create an independent redistricting commission that would draw new political boundaries every decade rallied this morning outside the Michigan Supreme Court as justices considered a lawsuit to keep the measure off the ballot.

[Rep: Schuette]  Schuette's office will argue against the proposal for an independent redistricting commission Wednesday and ask the Michigan Supreme Court to keep the measure off the November ballot.

Article summarizing the candidates stances on hot-button education issues. Schuette doesn't address many of the issues concerning education, like early childhood education and college tuition, but is clear on his support of charters. Whitmer has a thorough plan for education: she wants to address the teacher shortage by improving teacher preparation programs, institute a MI Opportunity Scholarship for community college students and stop the creation of more for-profit charters.
[Rep: Schuette] Interview with Schuette, main point: population growth the biggest issue of Michigan's future and intends to be the "jobs governor to grow the state."

A federal judge sided with the Trump administration over Planned Parenthood Monday, dismissing a lawsuit the women’s health organization brought against the administration’s guidelines for Title X funding. The judge said that the lawsuit was premature as the government hasn’t made decisions yet on which applicants will be awarded grant money.

Whitmer and El-Sayed clashed often in the democratic gubernatorial debate last night. El-Sayed accused Whitmer of “corruption” for raising campaign funds at a party hosted by health insurance executives. Whitmer touted her work in the state Senate on a bipartisan law to expand Medicaid eligibility under the Affordable Care Act and said she would fight Trump administration attempts to scale back the law.

[Dem: El-Sayed] Alexandria Ocasio Cortez, a democratic socialist who defeated an incumbent Democratic congressman last month in New York, has endorsed El-Sayed and is set to campaign for him here in late July. El-Sayed is attempting to build on the vision of  Bernie Sanders, who scored a surprise victory over Hillary Clinton in Michigan’s 2016 presidential primary by railing against corporate influence and trying to rally the youth vote.
Another study on Line 5 has been released, detailing how a spill would cause 437 miles of Great Lake shorelines to be damaged, endanger 47 wildlife species and 60,000 acres of habitat.
